verses.verse: After these things Jesus appeared again to the disciples at the Sea of Tiberias, and he showed himself in this way.
Simon Peter, Thomas (the twin), Nathaniel from Cana in Galilee, Zebedee's sons, and two other disciples were together.
Simon Peter said to them, "I am going fishing." They replied, "We are going with you, too." They immediately went out and entered a boat. That night they caught nothing.
But now when morning arrived, Jesus stood on the shore, but the disciples didn't know that it was Jesus.
Then Jesus said to them, "Children, have you any fish?" "No," they answered him.
He said to them, "Throw out the net on the right side of the boat, and you will get [some]." So they throw it out, but this time they weren't able to draw it in, because of so many fish.

Therefore that beloved disciple said to Peter, "It is the Lord". Now when Simon Peter heard that it was the Lord, he wrapped his fishing coat on (because he was naked), and threw himself into the water.
The other disciples came in a small boat (for they were not far from land only about two hundred cubits [about 300 feet/91.5 meters]) dragging the net with fish.
As soon as they came to land, they saw a fire of coals there with fish lying on it and bread.
Jesus said to them, "Bring some of the fish which you just caught."
Simon Peter went up and drew the net full of 153 big fish to land, and even though there were so many, still the net wasn't broken.
Jesus said to them, "Come, eat." None of the disciples dared ask him, "Who are you?" knowing that it was the Lord.
Then Jesus went and took bread and gave to them and fish likewise.
This is now the third time that Jesus appeared to his disciples after he had risen from the dead.

So after they had eaten, Jesus said to Simon Peter, "Simon, son of Jona, do you love me more than these?" He said to him, "Yes, Lord, you know that I love (care much about) you." He said, "Feed my lambs."
Again, the second time, he said to him, "Simon, son of Jona, do you love me?" He said to him, "Yes, Lord, you know that I love (care about) you." He said to him, "Feed my sheep".

He said to him a third time, "Simon, son of Jona, do you like me"? Peter was grieved because he said to him a third time, "Do you like me?" He said to him, "Lord, you know everything; you know that I like you." Jesus said to him, "Feed my sheep.

"Very truly, I say to you, when you were young, you would gird yourself and walk wherever you wanted to, but when you become old, you will stretch out your hands, and another will gird you and lead you were you don't want to go."
He said this indicating what kind of death he would glorify God with. After he said this, he said to him, "Follow me."
Peter then turned around and saw that beloved disciple behind him (the one who leaned close to Jesus at supper and said, "Lord, who is he who betrays you?").
Seeing this one, Peter said to Jesus, "Lord, what about him?"
Jesus said to him, "If I want him to remain until I come, what is it to you? You follow me."
So this saying was spread around the brethren that that disciple wouldn't die, but Jesus didn't say to him, "You will not die," but, "If I want him to remain until I come, what is it to you?"
This is that disciple who testifies about these things and wrote these things. We know his testimony is true.
There are many other things which Jesus did, which if every one would be written, I suppose that even the world itself couldn't contain the books that could be written. Amen.
